Wasn't Heracles his Roman name?
topics.author: 4fde4618945b700aa0002fff

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5425c7fd6368721ffa700100#post_5425c7fd6368721ffa700100
nope. His roman name was hercules. the greek name is heracles. named after hera so that maybe she would stop trying to kill him. 
Some wires got crossed somewhere down the line.

the planet names are kinda nice. Mars has a better ring to it than ares. 

oh and hey, even though he doesn't have the "Tortured hero" angle that hercules has, perseus was a crazy badass. 
The gods showed up one day and were like "hey, here's some stuff, go save a princess from a sea monster or something. Also you might need medusa's head so you should probably get on that." and he was like "k" AND HE JUST WENT AND DID IT LIKE IT AIN'T NO THANG

topics.body:
"@SquiggyBomb":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5425d1ac6368721f89eb0000#post_5425d1ac6368721f89eb0000
I'm not sure how I stand on that. It can be really nice to see a comic or novel adapted word for word as a movie but some things don't translate well. Like the watchmen movie (which I personally loved) had scenes that were basically live action versions of the comic panels and most of the dialogue was exactly from the comic. But alan moore's writing... I don't know, it can be sort of overdramatic when actually spoken out loud. 

And then you have the situations like you mentioned before with frollo where they make an element from the original story much more interesting. Another good example is the beowulf movie. Again, very flawed but I liked it. It makes  beowulf as a pathological liar. They expand on the stories behind grendel, grendel's mother, the king that preceded beowulf and the dragon and it basically paints the original story as being from the perspective of beowulf's companion who believes every word he says without a doubt.
topics.author: 500b587e7f123b1f230014a9
